main.head: 1990s
Mid-1990s
main.p: Mills's activities come under increasingly close scrutiny by Italian prosecutors investigating one of his clients, Silvio Berlusconi. Mills had set up offshore companies and trusts for the Italian prime minister's business empire, which prosecutors try to show had been used to dodge tax and convey under-the-counter payments to politicians. Prosecutors initially treat Mills as a prosecution witness.

In unrelated developments, it emerges Mills was a non-executive director of Benetton's Formula One team at a time when controversy rages over the decision by his wife, Tessa Jowell, then a health minister, not to ban F1 tobacco advertising.

Mills wants to invest in a fund. His bank lends him â‚¬650,000 secured upon the north London home he shares with Jowell. He pays off the bank loan using the $600,000 from the "B people". According to his 2004 letter, he does not inform the UK tax authorities of the $600,000 from the "B people".

p.ref: Mills lobbied a government minister for support
details of the "B people" loan emerge in the UK press

main.p: 2 March - A cabinet inquiry clears Jowell of breaching ministerial code as Mills did not tell her about the "B people" gift. By now, Mills has retracted the version of events he wrote in the 2004 letter to his accountant and claims the money came from a shipping magnate, Diagio Attanasio.
4 March - Mills and Jowell announce they are to separate after 27 years of marriage.

main.p: Italian appeal court rules on the 2009 verdict.
